newsitem.title: USA: UAW, GM reach tentative deal at Cadillac plant.
newsitem.headline: UAW, GM reach tentative deal at Cadillac plant.

text.p: General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union reached a tentative contract deal early on Saturday that averted a threatened strike at GM's Cadillac assembly plant in Detroit.

UAW spokesman Frank Joyce said the agreement was scheduled for a ratification vote by the 3,600 members of United Auto Workers Local 22 on Sunday. The deal is expected to keep GM's launch of its 1998 Cadillac Seville on track.

Workers streamed out of the plant in the Hamtramck, Mich. enclave in Detroit after an 11:59 p.m. EDT Friday deadline expired and began picketing, but union officials quickly said talks were continuing and no strike had been declared.
"They put the pen to the paper and signed the agreement at 3:15 a.m.," said GM spokeswoman Marsha Hall-Jenkins. Both she and UAW officials declined to reveal details of the settlement.

As in six strikes this year and numerous strike threats, the UAW demanded more jobs at the plant to replace retiring workers and ease a growing workload. GM resisted such moves, maintaining that it needed to shrink its workforce to become competitive with Ford Motor Co., Chrysler Corp., and Japanese automakers.
The plant on the Detroit-Hamtramck border is the only assembly site for Cadillacs, producing the Seville, DeVille and Eldorado models.

A prolonged walkout could have disrupted GM's ambitious launch plans for the '98 Seville, which it aims to position as a world class luxury car that can compete head-to-head with Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Lexus. GM will unveil the car next month in the German automakers' backyard, at the international auto show in Frankfurt, Germany.
Cadillac plans to build a right-hand-drive version of the car and hopes to export the Seville all over the world in a bid to shed its stuffy, land-yacht image.

A seven-week strike that started in April at GM's Oklahoma City assembly plant disrupted the launch of GM's mid-size Chevrolet Malibu and Oldsmobile Cutlass sedans, which were viewed as critical to GM's efforts to regain market share.

"The most damaging thing about the strike in Oklahoma City was that it forced the company to relaunch the Malibu," said Schroder Wertheim & Co. auto analyst John Casesa. "If the strike had not happened, that car would have better awareness and better sales."
GM sold a respectable 12,996 Malibus in July, but that still fell short of the Corsicas and Berettas it replaced, which had sales of 15,698 units for the month.
Analysts also worry that consumers' attention will be drawn away from the car by Honda's launch of an all-new Accord this autumn.
The strikes have been costly to GM, cutting second-quarter profits by $490 million and reducing its share of the domestic car and light truck market well below GM's 1997 goal of 33 percent.

The automaker also said Friday that a three-month walkout at a Pontiac, Michigan, truck plant and a six-day strike at a Warren, Michigan, transmission plant, forced it to cut its third-quarter production schedule by 20,000 vehicles.
